The  Kyrgyz  Republic  faces  difficult  development  challenges. 
Gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  growth  has  been  modest 
(averaging  around  5%  per  year  during  2003–2007)  and  volatile. 
While  official  figures  put  the  unemployment  rate  at  about  8%, 
actual unemployment and underemployment rates are believed to 
be considerably higher. Approximately 35% of the population lives 
below the poverty line, with 7% living in extreme poverty.   
 
The  Kyrgyz  Republic’s  population  of  just  over  5  million  means  a 
very small domestic market and limited potential for economies of 
scale in industrial production. Its integration with the global market 
is constrained by its geographic location and inadequate physical 
infrastructure. The country’s two major natural resources are gold 
and  hydropower.  However,  known  gold  reserves  are  being 
depleted without significant new discoveries being made, and the 
potential for exporting hydropower has not yet been fully realized.

The program cluster faces three main risks.  
 
Limited  Interagency  Coordination.  Investment climate reforms 
cut  across  various  subsectors,  and  require  close  coordination 
among relevant government agencies. The Program involves five 
IAs  and  lack  of  coordination  among  them  is  a  potential  risk.  The 
implementation  arrangements  are  designed  to  ensure  effective 
coordination  at  a  high  level  for  overall  policy  guidance,  at  a 
working  level  for  day-to-day  implementation  matters,  and  at  a 
technical  level.  The  involvement  of  the  Investment  Council—a 
high  level  forum  chaired  by  the  President  and  with  the  explicit 
mandate  to  coordinate  reforms—will  also  facilitate  interagency 
coordination.  Moreover,  ADB  is  currently  working  with  two  IAs  in 
the context of other ongoing projects (Banking Reform and Capital 
Market  Development  and  Customs  Modernization  and 
Infrastructure Development). This will further facilitate interagency 
coordination.  
 
Weak  Implementation  Capacity  and  High  Staff  Turnover. 
Another potential risks is weaknesses in implementation capacity 
and  high  staff  turnover,  especially  in  MEDT,  which  is  a  relatively 
new  ministry.  To  mitigate  this  risk,  the  attached  TA  places  a 
strong emphasis on capacity building and training.  MEDT’s ability 
to attract and retain qualified staff is also increasing gradually as 
its  profile  as  the  lead  agency  for  economic  planning  and  private 
sector  development  has  increased  in  recent  years.  In  addition,  a 
recently  approved  World  Bank  TA  focuses  on  strengthening 
MEDT  capacity  by  improving  human  resource  management  and 
developing comprehensive training curricula for MEDT staff. 

Unforeseen  Changes  in  Circumstances.  The  issues  to  be 
addressed  under  the  Program  are  mostly  structural  and  hence 
unlikely to change in the short term. However, the specific set of 
institutional solutions and mechanisms may need to be adapted to 
changes  in  circumstances  (e.g.  new  parallel  and  related  laws 
coming  into  effect  and  related  institutional  changes).  This  may 
require  different  solutions  to  the  original  problem.  The  proposed 
cluster  approach  will  help  mitigate  these  risks,  as  it  allows  for  a 
reassessment  of  the  way  forward  at  each  processing  stage  of 
subsequent subprograms.

B. 

Near-Term Prospects 

The  recent  deterioration  in  international  economic  conditions  has  brought  new 
5. 
macroeconomic  challenges  to  the  Kyrgyz  Republic.  The  economic  slowdown  in  neighboring 
Kazakhstan, in particular, will have important implications since Kazakhstan is one of the Kyrgyz 
Republic’s main trading partners and sources of foreign direct investment. While the contagion 
effect from the Kazakh banking sector appears to have been limited thus far, it may grow, given 
the  strong  presence  of  Kazakh-owned  banks  in  Kyrgyz  Republic.  The  sharp  decline  in 
construction activity in Kazakhstan has reduced the flow of remittances to the Kyrgyz Republic 
(a  major  source  of  balance  of  payments  inflows)  as  this  sector  employs  thousands  of  Kyrgyz 
nationals.  Largely  as  a  result  of  these  spillover  effects  from  Kazakhstan,  economic  growth 
(excluding gold production) is expected to slow to 5% in 2008. 
 
6. 
Moreover,  the  escalation  in  food  and  fuel  prices  since  late  2007  has  put  pressures  on 
the  authorities  for  policy  responses  that  have  diverse  fiscal  and  monetary  implications. 
Fundamentally,  the  authorities  face  tough  trade-offs  between  competing  macroeconomic 
objectives.  With  bank  reserves  and  broad  money  already  growing  and  significant  increases  in 
current public expenditures (salary increases of 30% and sizable increases in pension benefits) 
in  the  recent  past,  it  will  be  a  challenge  to  keep  inflation  under  control  and  at  the  same  time 
provide  safety  nets  to  the  population  most  affected  by  this  shock.  Concerns  have  been 
expressed that the current spike in imported inflation may become entrenched. The Government 
has  accordingly  signaled  its  intention  to  tighten  monetary  policy,  and  to  reduce  nonpriority 
current expenditures to enable discretionary spending to mitigate poverty impacts from the food 
and fuel crises.  
 
7. 
 To cushion the impact of the price shocks on low-income households, the Government 
recently  increased  cash  transfers  under  the  unified  monthly  benefit  scheme  by  Som35  (from 
Som125)  per  beneficiary.2 The  Government  has  budgeted  an  additional  Som650  million  ($19 
million)  for  a  variety  of  in-kind  support,  including  for  the  purchase  of  farm  equipment  and 
fertilizers  and  for  subsidized  wheat  for  low-income  households.  The  Government  has  also 
announced  a  Som100  million  loan  to  Ailbank  (Agriculture  Bank)  for  onlending  to  farmers  at 
below-market interest rates.    
 
8.

during the coming winter months significantly because of the critically low levels of water in the 
main  hydropower  generation  reservoir.  As  a  result,  the  International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF)

The Kyrgyz Republic’s near-term economic prospects have therefore become markedly 
more  uncertain  since  late  2007.  The  authorities  face  two  immediate  challenges:  (i)  securing 
financial resources and implementing effective and well-targeted safety net measures to protect 
those  worst  affected  by  the  food  and  fuel  crises;3 and  (ii)  formulating  appropriate  fiscal  and 
monetary  policies  in  view  of  the  trade-offs  highlighted  above.  Effective  management  of  these 
challenges  will  be  crucial  for  ensuring  macroeconomic  stability  as  well  as  for  maintaining 
momentum for reforms to improve the investment climate.

18. 
 Inefficiencies and uncertainty arising from the regulatory regime are major impediments 
to  private  sector  development.  Business  start-up  procedures  are  onerous,  and  the outcome  is 
unpredictable  because  of  lack  of  transparency  and  the  discretion  enjoyed  by  the  approving 
authorities.  Businesses  register  by  submitting  documents  (application  form,  company  charter 
and founder’s agreement) at the State Registration Department of the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) 
or  other  Justice  Administrations  in  Bishkek  city,  Osh  city,  and  the  seven  oblast  (province) 
centers.  Businesses  also  need  to  visit  and  register  at  the  State  Committee  for  Taxes  and 
Collection,  the  Social  Fund,  and  the  National  Statistical  Committee.  MOJ  then  conducts  a 
substantive review of registration documents to assess their compliance with a number of laws 
and regulations (e.g., the Civil Code and the Law on Registration of Legal Entities). This review 
process  is  a  major  bottleneck,  causing  considerable  delay,  and  is  a  significant  drain  on  MOJ 
resources.  
 
19. 
The Civil Code and other legislation govern how companies can be liquidated. However, 
there  is  no  easy  or  quick  means  to  liquidate  or  remove  from  the  register  a  company  which  is 
simply  inactive.  Several  thousand  of  the  40,000  registered  companies  are  believed  to  be 
dormant. This causes difficulties for the tax authorities and other regulatory bodies, as well as 
for  entrepreneurs  who  may  themselves  wish  to  liquidate  their  companies  but  are  discouraged 
from doing so because of the time and complexity of the procedures. If exit from a business is 
difficult and implies open-ended tax liabilities, establishing a formal business becomes a riskier 
proposition.

prevent their future proliferation.

Low Investment in Infrastructure and Utilities 

34. 
State  ownership  is  dominant  in  what  the  authorities  define  as  “strategic  assets”,  which 
include  almost  all  infrastructure.  Inadequate  resources  for  rehabilitation,  maintenance  and 
operation  have  resulted  in  a  serious  deterioration  in  many  infrastructure  assets  and  services.  
For  example,  road  transport  accounts  for  about  95%  of  movement  of  goods  and  people,  but 
because  of  past  neglect  of  routine  and  preventive  maintenance,  the  roads  are  in  a  distressed 
state. This translates into high freight transport costs that in turn increase overall production and 
marketing costs. Frequent interruptions in power supply also impose significant costs, especially 
on smaller businesses. This has been exacerbated by the heavy rationing of electricity in recent 
months resulting from the low water levels of the main hydropower reservoirs and the reduced 
output  of  the  main  thermal  power  plant.  Effective  infrastructure  services,  particularly  in  the 
energy  and  transport  sectors,  are  key  to  the  expansion  of  the  economy’s  productive  capacity. 
Without  adequate  maintenance  and  new  investments  in  infrastructure,  economic  growth  will 
continue to be constrained by power outages, traffic congestion, high transport costs, and other 
infrastructure bottlenecks.  
 
35. 
As outlined in the Government’s Country Development Strategy (CDS) 2007–2010, the 
Kyrgyz  Republic  has  significant  infrastructure  and  utilities  investment  needs.  Specifically, 
infrastructure spending needs to be boosted from the current 3–4% of GDP to at least 6%. This 
cannot be done from the government budget and external aid alone. 
 
36. 
The  Government  is  committed  to  creating  a  conducive  environment  for  private  sector 
participation  and  public–private  partnerships  (PPPs) 8  for  commercially  viable  infrastructure 
projects.  However, the legal, regulatory and institutional framework for PPPs is incomplete. For 
instance,  the  Concession  Law,  1992  only  covers  concessions  and  does  not  specify  other 
contractual  arrangements  suitable  for  PPPs.  Other  important  gaps  include:  (i)  the  absence  of 
procedures and  criteria for  concessionaire  selection,  (ii)  the lack  of  a  general  clause  for  tariffs 
and tariff adjustments in concessionaire agreements, and (iii) ambiguity about the availability of 
government support and financial guarantees. There is a need to strengthen both cross-sectoral 
and sector-specific laws and regulations. The fact that only one concession—for a gold mine—
has been awarded since 1992 may be at least partly attributable to these weaknesses. 
 
37.

ensure  a  consistent  approach  to  private  sector  participation  across  sectors.  Adequate  risk

Likewise,  there  is  a  need  to  develop  effective  mechanisms  and  build  capacity  for  project 
preparation and for transparent and competitive selection of private sector partners.

CDS.  The  CDS  was  prepared  through  extensive  stakeholder  consultations,  and  builds  on  the

Administrative  barriers  in  the  form  of  inefficient  regulation  and  excessive 
government  intervention  and  red  tape  constitute  the  single  most  important 
impediment  to  private  sector  development.  These  barriers  translate  into  direct 
costs as well as uncertainty, thereby deterring private investment. The recourse 
mechanisms  proposed  under  Program  will  reduce  this  risk  and  boost  business 
confidence.  By  streamlining  business  regulation  and  procedures,  the  Program 
will help promote investment and growth.  

Significant  progress  has  been  made  in  stabilizing  the  financial  sector  and 
strengthening the regulatory and supervisory framework.  As a result, confidence 
in  the  sector  has  strengthened  and  access  to  finance  has  improved.  However, 
the financial sector does not yet play a meaningful role in financial intermediation; 
interest rates and interest margins are high and loans are mostly short term. The 
Program will strengthen enforcement of financial contracts and credit information 
sharing among financial institutions, which will be fundamental to reducing credit 
risk  and  promoting  long-term  funds  for  investment.  The  Program’s  support  for 
leasing will help to expand financing for capital equipment. 

The  enabling  framework  for  PPP  will  help  attract  private  investment  in 
infrastructure,  which  will  significantly  reduce  the  costs  of  doing  business, 
especially  those  associated  with  high  transport  costs  and  an  unreliable  energy 
supply.  More  private  investment  in  infrastructure  will  generate  employment  and 
improve  incomes.  It  will  reduce  the  need  for  public  spending  in  infrastructure;  if 
this  saving  is  channeled  toward  social  spending,  PPPs  will  also  indirectly  help 
improve overall social welfare. 
Over  the  medium  to  long  term,  less  government  interference  and  red  tape  will 
encourage the large number of businesses that are currently operating informally 
to  enter  the  formal  sector.  This  will  generate  additional  tax  revenues.  More 
generally,  increased  private  sector  activity  will  enhance  tax  revenues,  thereby 
creating fiscal space for development expenditures.

banks,  or  for  specialized  legislation  to  govern  credit  information  sharing  mechanisms.  Such 
specialized  legislation  has  recently  been  recommended  in  the  Doing  Business  report,  but  in 
terms  of  sequencing,  the  Civil  Code  and  the  Law  on  Banking  need  to  be  amended  first.  The 
various  stakeholders  also  have  to  reach  a  consensus  on  the  overall  institutional  and  legal 
architecture  that  minimizes  the  legal  risks  in  the  positive  information  sharing  that  participating 
members  engage  in.  The  consensus  building  effort  and  the  assessment  of  different  technical 
and institutional options is yet to be initiated.  
 
29. 
The  CIB  system  is  generally  not  automatically  integrated  with  the  management 
information  systems  of  participating  banks,  which  means  that  the  daily  reporting  requirements 
impose a heavy burden on bank’s operations, as information about borrowers is input manually. 
The equivalent cost of this burden, in terms of the number of bank employees directly set aside 
for this task, is proportional to the market share of each bank. On the other hand, the perceived 
benefits of the CIB to the participating bank are inversely proportional to its market share. This 
cost–benefit  asymmetry  does  affect  the  reporting  compliance  of  each  bank,  and  the  CIB  is 
currently not perceived by a number of banks to be complete in any way.

32. 
The  Government  is  therefore  fully  committed  to  creating  an  environment  that  is 
conducive for private sector participation and for promoting public–private partnerships (PPPs)9 
for  commercially  viable  infrastructure  projects.  However,  the  legal,  regulatory  and  institutional 
framework  for  PPPs  is  incomplete.  For  instance,  the  Concession  Law,  1992  only  covers 
concessions and does not specify other sectors in which PPPs can be applied. Other important 
gaps include: (i) the absence of procedures and criteria for concessionaire selection, (ii) the lack 
of  a  general  clause  or  tariffs  and  tariff  adjustments  in  concessionaire  agreements,  and  
(iii) ambiguity about the availability or otherwise of government support and financial guarantees.   
There is a need to strengthen both cross-sectoral and sector-specific laws and regulations. The 
fact  that  only  one  concession–for  a  gold  mine–has  been  awarded  since  1992  may  be  at  least 
partly attributable to these weaknesses. 
 
33. 
A  conducive  environment  for  PPP  also  requires  an  effective  institutional  framework  to 
ensure  a  consistent  approach  to  private  sector  participation  across  sectors.  Adequate  risk 
mitigation and fair risk-sharing mechanisms between the public and private sectors are essential. 
Likewise,  there  is  a  need  to  develop  effective  mechanisms  and  build  capacity  for  project 
preparation and transparent and competitive selection of private sector partners.  
 
34.

recover their costs and earn an adequate rate of return. Current low tariff levels in the Kyrgyz 
Republic  are  a  legacy  of  the  centrally-planned  economy  when  infrastructure  services  were 
provided at a low or no cost, with tariffs bearing no relationship to the actual cost of supply.

A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
The  Government’s  medium-term  development  goals  are  outlined  in  the  Country  Development  Strategy  (CDS)  2007–2010, 
which builds on the National Poverty Reduction Strategy 2003–2005. The CDS focuses on four strategic pillars—enhancing 
economic growth potential, combating corruption, accelerating social development, and promoting environment sustainability.  
The CDS aims to achieve annual growth rates of 8.5% during 2008–2010. Likewise, it aims to increase per capita incomes 
substantially and to reduce the poverty rate to 30% in 2010. The investment required to meet these objectives is large. The 
CDS  therefore  places  a  strong  emphasis  on  improving  the  investment  climate  by  reducing  administrative  barriers,  creating 
favorable  tax  and  customs  regimes,  and  strengthening  the  financial  sector.  The  program  cluster  is  fully  aligned  with  the 
Government’s  priorities.  The  Program  is  also  included  in  the  Joint  Country  Support  Strategy  (JCSS)  2007–2010  prepared 
together  with  the  Department  for  International  Development  of  the  United  Kingdom,  Swiss  Cooperation,  United  Nations 
agencies and the World Bank Group.  
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification: General intervention 
1.  Key Issues  
 
With an annual per capita income of about $700, the Kyrgyz Republic is one of the poorest countries in Central Asia. Poverty 
peaked at about 60% in 1999 following the Russian economic crisis.  Although poverty incidence has declined since, it is still 
at a very high level of 35%.  Almost 7% of the population lives in extreme poverty.  About 75% of the poor live in rural areas.  
Progress toward meeting the Millennium Development Goals has been mixed and many of the targets may not be met if the 
country moves along its current path.     
 
Mitigating  the  poverty  impact  of  the  ongoing  food  crisis  is  one  of  the  most  pressing  challenges  currently  facing  the 
Government. While food producers  will probably benefit from rising food prices, the real incomes of the urban poor and the 
net food consumers in rural areas will be adversely affected.  As the poorest 20% of the population spend as much as 60% of 
their incomes on food, the poor will be the hardest hit by the food price hike.    
 
2. Design Features 
 
The Program will support employment generation and poverty reduction through high and sustainable economic growth.    

C.  Poverty Impact Analysis for Policy-Based Lending  
 
By  supporting  a  broadening  of  the  economic  base  and  thereby  reducing  the  country’s  vulnerability  to  external  shocks,  the 
Program  will  support  the  Government’s  poverty  reduction  efforts  through  higher  and  sustainable  economic  growth.  The 
Program will enhance tax revenues by encouraging businesses that are currently operating informally to come into the formal 
sector  and  by  expanding  private  sector  activities  in  general,  as  well  as  by  reducing  the  need  for  public  spending  on 
infrastructure.  This in turn will enable more social spending and other development expenditures that directly benefit the poor.
